title: Scenario
scenario: During a casual lab dinner, one male student keeps making jokes about a female member’s body, and she looks embarrassed.

options.label: Lightly step in and shift the topic so everyone can move on naturally.
After the dinner, quietly check in with her to see how she feels.
Later discuss with several core members whether to remind him about his words.
Take note of it for now and only bring it up if it happens again.

title: Scenario
scenario: You see someone post a meme with sexual undertones in your lab’s public chat group.

options.label: Ignore it and let the chat move on naturally.
Privately remind the sender that such content might cause misunderstanding.
Share a light academic meme next time to shift the overall tone.
Keep a record, and if it happens again, consider informing the advisor.

title: Scenario
scenario: A female lab mate tells you that her collaborator often stands too close during one-on-one discussions, making her uncomfortable.

options.label: Encourage her to express her boundary in a calm, natural way.
Offer to accompany her to briefly mention this to the advisor.
Suggest keeping all future talks in open spaces.
Show understanding and share some relaxation or communication tips.

title: Scenario
scenario: A teammate didn’t cite your code contribution in a shared paper draft.

options.label: Calmly bring it up and ask whether it was an oversight.
Privately message the first author to discuss proper attribution.
Add a subtle footnote crediting your part in the next revision.
Say nothing—it’s the team’s collective output anyway.

title: Scenario
scenario: Your advisor asks you to take the lead on a new sub-project that overlaps with another student’s work.

options.label: Talk to the other student first to clarify boundaries before starting.
Start working immediately and deal with any overlap later.
Ask the advisor to assign tasks more clearly between you two.
Propose merging both works into a collaborative version.

title: Scenario
scenario: You notice that a small informal chat group in the lab is spreading gossip about another member’s personal life.

options.label: Gently remind everyone not to share unverified stories.
Suggest that the group admin post a note reminding everyone to stay respectful.
Privately check in with the person being discussed to make sure they’re aware.
Stay silent and assume the issue will fade by itself.

title: Scenario
scenario: A visitor from another university compliments a female student in your lab in an overly romantic way during a tour.

options.label: Smoothly redirect the topic back to research.
Check with the student afterward to see if she minded it.
Tell your advisor afterward so similar visits can be better managed.
Bring it up during the next group meeting as a reminder of etiquette.

title: Scenario
scenario: You realize a teammate repeatedly claims credit for shared visualization work during presentations.

options.label: Privately talk to them to clarify the contribution and future attributions.
Raise the issue with the advisor to keep things transparent.
Add subtle notes in your slides showing who built what.
Let it go—it’s team work and not worth conflict.

title: Scenario
scenario: Two lab members are arguing loudly over who should control the shared GPU node during a late-night session.

options.label: Calmly suggest creating a usage schedule for fair access.
Ignore it unless it directly delays your own work.
Tell your advisor the next morning to avoid escalation.
Step in and mediate by proposing they take turns this time.

title: Scenario
scenario: You realize a junior student is struggling to reproduce your past experiment but hasn’t asked for help.

options.label: Ask if they’d like you to walk them through your code.
Leave them some hints in the repo without directly intervening.
Inform your advisor so that assistance can be reassigned.
Let them find their own way—it’s a learning process.

title: Scenario
scenario: A lab friend shares some preliminary results with you and asks for feedback, but you notice several clear calculation errors.

options.label: Kindly point out the mistakes and suggest rechecking before showing others.
Give light feedback to avoid discouraging them.
Say nothing and let them find the issue themselves.
Privately tell another senior student to help review.

title: Scenario
scenario: You suspect that another student is using lab data without formal permission for a side project.

options.label: Talk to them privately to confirm before making assumptions.
Directly notify the advisor since it may affect data policy.
Ask mutual friends whether they know about it.
Wait and see if the issue affects you before reacting.

title: Scenario
scenario: Your paper is rejected with harsh comments that seem emotionally biased.

options.label: Discuss the feedback calmly with your advisor to find what’s still useful.
Vent privately, then move on and resubmit to another venue.
Post your review experience online to gather sympathy.
Complain to co-authors that the reviewers were unqualified.

title: Scenario
scenario: You and a teammate disagree on how to visualize an experiment result.

options.label: Propose trying both versions and compare clarity objectively.
Let them decide since it’s not critical to your part.
Ask a neutral lab member to review both designs.
Push for your version since it aligns with your vision.

title: Scenario
scenario: You notice a senior member frequently takes credit when presenting joint results with junior members.

options.label: Talk privately and express that shared credit matters for motivation.
Raise it indirectly in a future lab meeting as a group concern.
Encourage the junior member to bring it up themselves.
Ignore it since hierarchy is normal in labs.

title: Scenario
scenario: A classmate outside your lab asks for internal code that’s under NDA with an industry partner.

options.label: Decline politely and explain it’s under a confidentiality agreement.
Share a simplified version without revealing details.
Ask your advisor for permission before sharing anything.
Tell them to check online repositories instead.

title: Scenario
scenario: A collaborator uploads an unfinished draft to a shared drive visible to outsiders.

options.label: Privately remind them to check the sharing settings.
Immediately remove the access link if you can.
Warn them in the group chat about the visibility issue.
Leave it alone since it’s their file, not yours.

title: Scenario
scenario: A new intern in the lab often speaks during group meetings but rarely listens to feedback.

options.label: Gently remind them to balance speaking and listening.
Ask your advisor to guide them in a private chat.
Talk to them informally about lab meeting culture.
Stay silent—it’s not your responsibility.

title: Scenario
scenario: You notice a senior member constantly interrupts others during discussion.

options.label: Lightly interject with humor to redirect the floor.
Privately suggest to them to let others finish speaking.
Mention in the next meeting that everyone should take turns.
Ignore it—it’s part of their personality.

title: Scenario
scenario: You realize that your own tone sounded harsh when replying to a junior in the chat group.

options.label: Apologize and clarify your intention to avoid misunderstanding.
Message them privately to explain, without making it public.
Leave it alone—no one seemed offended.
Post something lighthearted later to smooth the atmosphere.
